items.description: Upper Bristol Avon area
items.message:
Rain has fallen over the weekend due to the effects of Storm Bert. River levels are falling but remain higher than usual. Areas most at risk include locations near the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon, Dauntsey Brook.

Further rain is forecast overnight and river levels are likely to increase moderately in response. Flooding is possible through Wednesday before conditions begin to improve.

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 27/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Torksey river gauge as a result of rainfall.  Consequently, the possibility of flooding of low-lying roads and farmland is expected to continue.  Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road.   
  We expect river levels to remain high until 28/11/2024.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 10:00 tomorrow morning, 27/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

There is more rainfall forecast in the next 24 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid contact with flood water and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 18:00 on 26/11/24, or as the situation changes.

There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. 

We will continue to monitor levels closely and reissue flood warnings and alerts when necessary.

items.description: Lower Nene
items.message: River levels remain high following recent heavy rainfall in the River Nene catchment. The Lower River Nene is now rising, and will remain high over the next few days, which will lead to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. Flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties is likely, and therefore flood warnings are expected to be issued from tomorrow. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine on Wednesday 27th November, or before if the situation changes.

Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning Wednesday 27/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ray for Islip
items.message:

Therefore, flooding of property and roads is expected to continue between Lower Arncott and Islip overnight, 26/11/2024. Areas most at risk are properties located closest to the river on Mill Street​. 
The forecast is for further rainfall forecast tonight (26/11/2024) into tomorrow. River levels between Lower Arncott and Islip are expected to continue to drop slowly overnight. Levels remain sensitive to further rainfall and may rise again later this week in response to the forecast rainfall.  
Move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety. Activate any property flood protection products such as flood barriers. Do not drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 27/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels remain high throughout the South East Somerset area following the weekend's heavy rain. Consequently, flooding of roads and low lying land is possible on Tuesday 26/11/2024.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Yeo, River Cam, and River Wriggle, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole.

Tuesday is forecast to be mainly dry, however rainfall is forecast from 7PM on Tuesday evening, clearing early on Wednesday morning. We expect rivers to respond to this. We are monitoring the situation closely, and staff have been out checking rivers for blockages and clearing weed screens.

Monitor local water levels and weather conditions, and avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Don't put yourself or others at risk.

This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 27/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:

This information is correct as of 15:05 on Tuesday 26/11/2024. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 8 centimetres of water on the road. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. 
There are currently no issues on the Earith or Welney causeway. 
We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 8am tomorrow, Wednesday 27/11/2024.

items.description: Combe Haven
items.message: Between 15-30mm of rain is forecast through the early hours of Wednesday 27/11/24. There remains uncertainty, but if as much rain falls as predicted, flooding could be possible. From 03:00 on 27/11/2024, minor flooding could affect fields, rural roads and gardens of a small number of properties in Crowhurst. Potentially including Crowhurst Recreation Ground, riverside properties on Forewood Lane, and properties between the Plough public house and the junction of Sampsons Lane on Sandrock Hill. From 08:00 on 27/11/2024, a small amount of water may also affect Bexhill Road Recreation Ground in Bulverhythe. Almost no rainfall is predicted Wednesday afternoon, through to the weekend. The river should begin to fall in Crowhurst by 15:00 on 27/11/2024, and should return to normal from 22:00 on 27/11/2024. It is thought river levels could end up a little higher than following Storm Bert. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Crowhurst, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 14:00 on 27/11/2024

We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is stable at 8.90 m. The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.91 m and is rising very slowly. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this drain level exceeds 7.3m, the road from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86m, the road from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93m and the road from Muchelney to Draycott, Law Lane, above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m.
Pumping will start at Huish Episcopi and Westover pumping stations when river levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel will be opened once Parrett spillways stop running.
Tuesday will be mainly dry, however, there will be further rainfall from 7pm which will clear through the early hours of Wednesday.
The situation is being continually monitored and staff are checking the condition of flood banks, spillways and weed screens. Refer to https://www.somerset.gov.uk/roads-travel-and-parking/emergency-road-closure-gates for details of local road closures.
This message will be updated by 2 PM on 27/11/2024 or as the situation changes.

items.message: The water level in the River Blackwater at Ower and Cadnam River continues to fall following heavy rainfall over the weekend, when 56mm of rain was recorded in Romsey.  Later this evening (Tuesday 26/11/24) further heavy rain is forecast with up to 40mm expected. If this rain impacts the river, then flooding of land, roads and a small number of properties is expected. It is possible that a Flood Warning will be reissued tomorrow. The weather will be dry from Thursday (28/11/24) to Saturday (30/11/24) so any flood impacts which do occur, will be relatively short term in nature.  Our operations staff will work to ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. Please ensure that pumps used to protect property are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on 27/11/24.

items.message: Between 15 and 30mm of rain is forecast through the early hours of Wednesday. There remains uncertainty, but if as much rain falls as predicted, flooding could be possible. From 04:00 27/11/2024 minor flooding could affect fields, rural roads, and gardens of properties on Mill Lane, Hellingly, and Grove Hill near Grovebridge Farm. From 08:00 27/11/2024 flood impacts could also affect gardens of Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. From 12:00 27/11/2024 minor flooding could also affect North Street, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. Almost no rainfall is predicted Wednesday afternoon, through to the weekend. The rivers in Hellingly should begin to fall by 18:00 27/11/2024, returning to normal by Thursday morning. In Alfriston, river levels will not begin to fall until Thursday. Plan to avoid driving on routes susceptible to flooding, including Mill Lane and Church Road, Hellingly, and North Street, Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 16:00 27/11/2024.

The river will be high through Uckfield. From 08:00 27/11/2024 flood water could affect fields and gardens in Isfield. Almost no rainfall is predicted Wednesday afternoon through to the weekend. The river should begin to fall by 15:00 27/11/2024 in Buxted, returning to normal by Thursday morning. In Isfield, river levels should begin to fall by 21:00 27/11/2024, returning to normal by midday Thursday. It is thought river levels could end up a little higher than following Storm Bert. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Buxted and Isfield, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 13:00 27/11/2024.

Haw Bridge 5m to 5.3m Tuesday night 26/11/2024,  

Sandhurst 3.6m to 3.9m Wednesday 27/11/2024,

items.description: Lower Stour at Redhill and Wheatplot Home Sites

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message:
High river levels are causing flooding throughout the afternoon.
Flooding is expected to continue until 10:00 AM on 27/11/2024.
Areas most at risk include Redhill and Wheatplot Home Sites.
Further rainfall is forecast overnight which may keep river levels high.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and liaising with emergency services and local authorities.
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
Refer to local authority website for road closures.
This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 27/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Stour from Sturminster Marshall to Christchurch

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message:
River levels are very slowly falling at the Throop and Iford gauges.
Flooding is expected to affect locations near the Lower Dorset Stour, Middle Dorset Stour, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around farms at Sturminster Marshall, Cowgrove, Shops in Wimborne, Mill Street in Corfe Mullen, Bridge House Hotel in Ferndown, Brecon Close, Ringwood Road, Throop Road in Bournemouth, Barrack Road and Willow Way in Christchurch.
Weather conditions are expected to be dry today with between 10-15mm of rain expected overnight tonight.  River levels may remain above the Flood Warning threshold for some time. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please consider activating any property flood protection products and start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Move family, pets and cars to safety and turn off gas, electricity and water if it is safe to do so. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 27/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Flooding is possible overnight on Tuesday 26th November.  

River levels in the Upper Tamar have dropped but further rainfall is expected over Tuesday night. Catchments are wet due to heavy rain associated with Storm Bert. Forecast rainfall tonight is likely to raise river levels and may cause flooding to low lying land and roads close to rivers.  River levels will remain high throughout Tuesday and Wednesday. 

Take care near areas of concern and avoid walking or driving through floodwater.  Monitor your local weather conditions and check river levels on gov.uk. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area clearing blockages. This message will be updated by 11am on Wednesday or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: West Somerset Streams

floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message:
River levels in the West Somerset area remain high following the weekend's heavy rain. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible throughout Tuesday 26/11/2024.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, and Doniford Stream, with low lying land and roads expected to be most impacted.

Tuesday is forecast to be mainly dry however rainfall is forecast from 7PM on Tuesday evening, clearing early on Wednesday morning. We expect rivers to respond to this. We are monitoring the situation closely, and staff have been out checking rivers for blockages and clearing weed screens.

Please remain aware of local water levels and weather conditions, and avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 27/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Wey
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high on the Upper River Wey as a result of heavy rainfall due to Storm Bert. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 26/11/24, especially in the Tilford and Godalming areas. The forecast is predominantly dry day with further rainfall forecast tonight (26/11/2024) into tomorrow. We expect river levels to remain high, but to start to fall today and tomorrow. We will continue to monitor the situation.
Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 27/11/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn Vyrnwy confluence
items.message:
River levels remain high but are falling at the Llanymynech and Maesbrook river gauges and remains high but steady at the Cae Howel river gauge following heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Minor roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre start to flood.  

 

Observed peak:-  Llanymynech 4.49m at 16:15 on Sunday, 24/11/24. 

 

No further significant rainfall is expected over the next 48 hours but showers are possible. 

We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days.  

 

We are closely monitoring the situation.   

 

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.    

 

This message will be updated by 10:00 on Wednesday 27/11/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Sow and River Penk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook

items.message:
River levels have returned to normal levels across most of the Sow and Penk. However, at the Milford river gauge levels still remain high and therefore the risk of flooding remains following the weekend rainfall from Storm Bert.  Flooding of roads and farmland will continue throughout Tuesday.  Flooding is expected to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Sow between Great Bridgeford and Shugborough, the River Penk between Coven and Stafford, the Sandyford Brook, the Rising Brook, the Ridings Brook and the Saredon Brook.   
There is the potential for light rainfall on Wednesday morning, but we do not expect any impacts as a result. 
We continue to closely monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are out checking defences and clearing screens, and we are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
This message will be updated on 27/11/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Tone and Parrett Moors
items.message:
Rising water levels in Currymoor are expected to cause flooding on Tuesday 26/11/2024. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Tone and on Currymoor, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected. New Road has been closed.
The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is falling slowly and is 7.47 m. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45m. The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 6.79 m and is stable. Pumping will start at Currymoor Station as soon as the river level allows. We are closely monitoring the situation.
Tuesday will be a mainly dry day, however, there will be further rainfall from 7pm which will clear through the early hours of Wednesday morning.
Plan driving routes to avoid New Road in Currymoor, which is affected by flooding. Don't put yourself or others at risk. Refer to https://www.somerset.gov.uk/roads-travel-and-parking/emergency-road-closure-gates/ for details of road closures.
This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 27/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

Diglis 4.74m and Kempsey Yacht Club 6.93m Monday evening 25/11/2024.

Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected to continue.  

We expect flooding to affect the B4213 at Haw Bridge.  

Predicted peak: 

Haw Bridge 5m to 5.3m Tuesday night, 26/11/2024.     

 
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  

We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and Local Authorities.    
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water.    
This message will be updated by 11am, Wednesday 27/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Wye from Hereford to Ross-On-Wye
items.message:
River levels are falling but remain high at the Ross-On-Wye river gauge following heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect properties and roads in and around Hereford and Ross on Wye including Wilton area.  

 

Observed peaks:- Mordiford 5.08m at 12:30 on Monday, 25/11/24, Ross on Wye 4.66m at 06:00 on Tuesday, 26/11/24.  

 

No further significant rainfall is expected over the next 48 hours but showers are possible. We expect river levels to remain high for several days.  

  

We are closely monitoring the situation.   

  

Please activate any property flood protection products you may have, such as flood barriers and air brick covers and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.   

  

This message will be updated by 11:00 on Wednesday 27/11/24, or as the situation changes

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message:
Groundwater levels have risen in response to recent rainfall. Levels are expected to continue to rise and flooding of fields and roads is possible. Levels are reactive to further rainfall. Further rainfall is expected over the next few days with upto 20mm expected to fall over the next few days, which could see levels continue to rise.

Flooding of roads and fields is possible. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 3 PM on 3/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Exe area
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: Flooding is possible overnight on Tuesday 26th November. River levels in the Lower Exe Area have dropped but further rainfall is expected over Tuesday night. Catchments are wet due to heavy rain associated with Storm Bert. Forecast rainfall tonight is likely to raise river levels and may cause flooding to low lying land and roads close to rivers. River levels will remain high throughout Tuesday and Wednesday. Take care near areas of concern and avoid walking or driving through floodwater. Monitor your local weather conditions and check river levels on gov.uk. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area clearing blockages. This message will be updated by 12pm on Wednesday or earlier if the situation changes.

items.message:

Further rain is forecast overnight and river levels are likely to increase moderately in response. Flooding is possible through Wednesday before conditions begin to improve.

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 27/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Witham in South Kesteven
items.message: River levels remain high in the River Witham following recent heavy rainfall in the South Kesteven area, which has led to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties is not likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine on Wednesday 27th November, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Sor Brook and The Bloxham Brook and their tributaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Sor, Bloxham Brook, Hornton Stream

items.message:
Property flooding remains possible. The flood warning is currently in force for the Sor Brook at Bodicote and Adderbury and the Bloxham Brook. River levels have now fallen on the Sor and Bloxham Brooks following heavy rainfall from Storm Bert. Further rainfall tonight may cause levels to rise again. Therefore, flooding of low lying land, roads, and property remains possible overnight, 26/11/24.
The forecast for today is dry with further rain tonight into tomorrow. River levels are expected to continue falling through today but may respond again overnight.
Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 27/11/24, or earlier as the situation changes.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Broadmead Brook, River Boyd, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly low lying land at Hanham Lock and the floodplain upstream of Bath.

Further rain is forecast overnight and river levels are likely to increase moderately in response. Flooding is possible through Wednesday before conditions begin to improve.

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 27/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Avon at Strensham and Bredon
items.message:
River levels remain high but are now falling at the Evesham river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  

Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected to continue.  

We expect flooding to affect properties and roads around Mill Lane, Strensham. 

Peak:- Evesham 3.06m Monday evening, 25/11/2024.  

Predicted peak:- Bredon 3.1m to 3.2m on Tuesday morning, 26/11/2024.     

Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  

We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.  

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and Local Authorities.   Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water.    

This message will be updated by 11am, Wednesday 27/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is expected. The flood warning for the River Cherwell from below Banbury to just above Upper Heyford is currently in force. River levels have are high but falling steadily on the upper River Cherwell following heavy rainfall from Storm Bert. Therefore, flooding of low lying land, roads, and property is expected to continue today, 26/11/24. The forecast for today is dry with further rainfall tonight into tomorrow. We expect river levels to continue to drop steadily through today. Levels are sensitive to further rainfall and may rise again in response to forecast rainfall. We are monitoring the situation. 
Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 27/11/24, or earlier as the situation changes.

Areas most at risk are Caldecote Lane, Willen Road, River Side, Toll House, Woad Farm, Sherington Road and Gallards Farm in Newport Pagnell, and Ravenstone Mill in Ravenstone.

items.description: Sor Brook at Bodicote and Adderbury and The Bloxham Brook
items.message:
Property flooding remains possible. River levels have now dropped on the Sor and Bloxham Brooks following rainfall from Storm Bert. Further rainfall tonight may bring levels back up to the flood risk threshold and therefore this warning will remain in force overnight. Flooding of property, land and roads is possible overnight 26/11/2024. Areas at risk are those closest to the Sor Brook in Bodicote, and on Dog Close in Adderbury. 
The forecast is for further rainfall tonight (26/11/2024) into tomorrow. Levels are expected to continue to fall this evening, but are likely to respond again to tonight's rainfall. Move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety. Have a bag ready with vital items like medicines and insurance documents. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 27/11/24, or earlier as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent in Nottinghamshire
items.message:
River levels are slowly rising at the Shardlow river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding of low-lying roads and farmland remains.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including communities near to the River Trent, and cellars of low-lying properties at Cavendish Bridge.   
No further significant rainfall is forecast.  We expect river levels to remain high until 28/11/2024.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 10:00 tomorrow morning, 27/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Burton Trent
items.message:
River levels have peaked at Croxall, but continue to rise at the Drakelow river gauge as a result of rainfall associated with Storm Bert.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected during Tuesday and possibly into Wednesday.  Flooding is expected to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Trent between Kings Bromley to Clay Mills including Burton upon Trent. 
There is the potential for light rainfall on Wednesday morning, but we do not expect any impacts as a result. 
We continue to closely monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are out checking defences and clearing screens, and we are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
This message will be updated on 27/11/24, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but slowly falling at the Harnham Bridge River Level gauge after the recent rainfall over the weekend. 
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle Hampshire Avon, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Lower Road and Church Lane.
We are closely monitoring the situation. A further 10-15mm of rain is forecast overnight tonight which may keep river levels high.
Please consider activating any property flood protection products and start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Move family, pets and cars to safety and turn off gas, electricity and water if it is safe to do so. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 27/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

Please consider activating any property flood protection products and start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Move family, pets and cars to safety and turn off gas, electricity and water if it is safe to do so. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

items.description: River Nene at Billing Aquadrome and nearby business parks
items.message: The severe flood warning for the Billing Aquadrome and nearby business parks remains in force, due to deep and fast flowing water which remains on the park. The situation remains hazardous. This means there is danger to life and you must act now. Call 999 if in immediate danger and follow advice from emergency services. Keep yourself and your family safe. Severe flooding is expected to continue. Please stay evacuated from the area. We will be closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated online and on FloodLine by Wednesday 27th November, or before if the situation changes.

Therefore, flooding of property and roads is expected to continue overnight, 26/11/2024, especially in the Enslow and Lower Heyford areas.  Areas most at risk include Watermead Road, Kidlington.  The forecast is for further rainfall tonight (26/11/2024) into tomorrow. River levels are expected to continue to drop slowly this evening. Levels remain sensitive to further rainfall and may rise again later in the week in response to forecast rain.

Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 27/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Evesham River gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect properties and roads in the Waterside road area as well as the road and car park on the meadow. Pershore Road Bridge may now be flooding. 
Peak:- Evesham 3.06m Monday 25/11/2024. 
We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid contact with flood water and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated by 11:00 tomorrow, Wednesday 27/11/2024, or if the situation changes.

items.description: River Avon at Stanford on Avon
Curry Moor and Hay Moor
items.message:
Rising water levels in Currymoor are expected to cause flooding on Tuesday 26/11/2024. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Tone and on Currymoor, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected. New Road has been closed.
The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is falling slowly and is 7.47 m. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45m. The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 6.79 m and is stable. Pumping will start at Currymoor Station as soon as the river level allows. We are closely monitoring the situation.
Tuesday will be a mainly dry day, however, there will be further rainfall from 7pm which will clear through the early hours of Wednesday morning.
Plan driving routes to avoid New Road in Currymoor, which is affected by flooding. Don't put yourself or others at risk. Refer to https://www.somerset.gov.uk/roads-travel-and-parking/emergency-road-closure-gates/ for details of road closures.
This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 27/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels in the River Welland remain high following recent heavy rainfall in the Lower Welland area, leading to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Ross on Wye 4.66m at 06:00 on Tuesday, 26/11/24.  

Lydbrook 6.43m at 04:00 on Tuesday, 26/11/24,

items.message:
Property flooding is expected. River levels are high but starting to stabilise on the River Thames following heavy rainfall from Storm Bert. The forecast is for further rainfall tonight (26/11/2024) into tomorrow. River levels are expected to continue to rise slowly downstream of Radcot overnight, while levels further upstream are expected to remain high and stable. We are monitoring the situation and operating our weirs to manage flood risk. Our staff are liaising with councils and emergency services. Move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety. Activate any property flood protection products such as flood barriers. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 27/11/24, or earlier as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames from Calcutt to Lechlade including Hannington Wick
items.message:

Therefore, flooding of property and roads remains possible overnight, 26/11/24. Areas most at risk are properties located closest to the River Thames in Hannington Wick and St Johns Priory.
The forecast is for further rainfall from tonight (26/11/2024) into tomorrow. River levels are expected to fall very slowly overnight. We are monitoring the situation. Our staff are liaising with councils and emergency services. Move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety. Activate any property flood protection products such as flood barriers. Do not drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 27/11/24, or earlier as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at Dunns Lane, Upton upon Severn
items.message:
River levels remain high but are falling slowly at the Saxons Lode river gauge because of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected to continue.  

We expect flooding to affect Dunns Lane, Upton upon Severn. Dunns Lane gate closed.  

Observed peak:- Saxons Lode 5.07m on Tuesday morning, 26/11/2024. 

Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  

We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and Local Authorities. Please move possession and valuables off the ground or to safety.  

This message will be updated by 11am, Wednesday 27/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today 26/11/2024, especially in the Sunbury and Molesey areas. The forecast is a predominantly dry day with further rainfall forecast tonight (26/11/2024) into tomorrow.  Our staff are managing weirs on the River Thames to reduce flood risk. items.description: Areas near the River Nene from Elton to Wansford
items.message: We have seen heavy rain in the River Nene catchment which has caused the River Nene to rise significantly. Levels are expected to remain high for the next few days. Low lying areas near the River are already flooded and we expect properties and access to Yarwell Mill Country Park to be affected overnight, Tuesday 26th November, and into Wednesday 27th. Other areas, including properties on London Road in Wansford, and Mill Lane, Waters View and Marina Terrace in Yarwell, may also be affected. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings. Please avoid contact with flood water. Our staff are out in the area to check the flood defences, clear blockages, and assist the emergency services and council. We will be closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated online and on FloodLine on Wednesday 27th November, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Stour at Jumpers Common and A35 Iford Bridge area, Christchurch
items.message:
High river levels are causing flooding throughout the afternoon.
Flooding is expected to continue until 10:00 AM on 27/11/2024.
Areas most at risk include River Glade, Dukesfield, Squirrels Cl, Stour Way, Links Dr, Burford Cl, Cedar Av, Chestnut Av, Beech Av, Sycamore Cl, River Way, Hurn Way, Wilton Cl, Stourcroft Dr, Crossways, De Redvers Court, Oak Av, The Grove and Stourvale Ave in Christchurch.
Further rainfall of 10-15mm is forecast overnight which may keep river levels high.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and liaising with emergency services and local authorities.
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions.
Refer to local authority website for road closures.
Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.
This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 27/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ock at Abingdon and Caldecott
items.message:

Areas most at risk are properties located closest to the River Ock on Mill Paddock, Orpwood Way, St Helens Mill, Nash Drive.
The forecast is for further rainfall tonight (26/11/2024) into tomorrow. River levels are expected to continue dropping slowly overnight. Levels remain sensitive to further rainfall and may rise again in response to forecast rainfall. We are monitoring the situation. Our staff are liaising with councils and emergency services. Move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety. Activate any property flood protection products such as flood barriers. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 27/11/24, or earlier as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Stour at Beaulieu Garden Park Home Site
items.message:
River levels are high but slowly falling due to the recent rainfall. Flooding is possible.  Flooding is affecting locations near the Lower Dorset Stour, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Beaulieu Garden Park Home Site.
There is 10-15mm of rain forecast overnight, so river levels may remain above the Flood Warning threshold for some time. We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please consider activating any property flood protection products and start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Move family, pets and cars to safety and turn off gas, electricity and water if it is safe to do so. Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals. Try to avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. 
This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 27/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

items.message:
Property flooding is possible. River levels are rising steadily on the River Thames following heavy rainfall from Storm Bert and water moving downstream. Therefore, flooding of property, low lying land and roads is possible from this afternoon, 26/11/24. Levels are expected to be lower than those seen in January 2024. Areas most at risk are properties closest to the Thames on Waters Edge, Bridge Street, East St. Helens Street .
The forecast is for a predominantly dry remainder of the day with further rainfall forecast overnight (26/11/2024) into tomorrow. River levels are expected to continue to rise steadily overnight before stabilising through the day tomorrow. Our staff are liaising with councils and emergency services and operating weirs on the Thames to manage flood risk. Move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety. Activate any property flood protection products such as flood barriers. Do not drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 27/11/24, or earlier as the situation changes.

items.description: Aldingbourne and Barnham Rifes
items.message: Between 15 and 30mm of rain is forecast through the early hours of Wednesday 27/11/2024. There remains uncertainty, but if as much rain falls as predicted, flooding could be possible. From 01:00 on 27/11/2024, minor flooding could affect Lake Lane and Barnham Road, Barnham. From 08:00 on 27/11/2024, flood water could also affect land around caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre, parts of the Tescos on Shripney Road, and fields near Shripney Lane and the A259. Almost no rainfall is predicted for Wednesday afternoon, through to the weekend. The Barnham Rife should begin to fall by 12:00 on 27/11/2024, and should return to normal by 17:00 on 27/11/2024. In Bersted, the Aldingbourne Rife might not begin to fall until 21:00 on 27/11/2024. River levels should end up a little higher than following Storm Bert. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Barnham, if you have them. We are clearing grilles through Barnham, including at the Trading Post, and our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 18:00 on 27/11/2024.

items.description: River Lox
items.message: Between 15 and 30mm of rain is forecast through the early hours of Wednesday 27/11/2024. There is uncertainty, but if as much rain falls as predicted, flooding could be possible. From 08:00 on 27/11/2024 flooding could affect fields, rural roads, and gardens along the length of the River Lox, approach properties near Brewhurst Mill on Brewhurst Lane and the Onslow Arms, Loxwood, and isolated riverside properties at Loxley Bridge on Wrotham Hill, Dunsfold. Flood water may also affect riverside properties on Petworth Road, Chiddingfold. Rain could be intense, minor surface water flooding could affect some riverside locations in Loxwood village. Almost no rainfall is predicted for Wednesday afternoon, through to the weekend. The river should begin to fall by 02:00 on 28/11/2024, and should return to normal by Friday. River levels could end up a little higher than following Storm Bert. Please continue to operate private water control structures at Brewhurst to reduce the risk of flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 16:00 on 27/11/2024.

items.description: River Great Ouse at Oakley and Clapham
items.message:
River levels are rising steadily in response to rainfall from Storm Bert. Flooding is possible from now, through the evening and tomorrow 26/11/2024 & 27/11/2024. 
Areas most at risk are College Farm at Oakley, and Folly Park, High Street, The Close, The Warren, Preservine Walk, Ursula Taylor Walk and Bedford Road in Clapham.  
Further rainfall is expected over the next 24 hours which will keep river levels high. 
Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. We are monitoring the situation.  We will update this message by10am tomorrow, 27/11/2024.

items.description: Langney Haven
items.message: Between 15-30mm of rain is forecast through the early hours of Wednesday (27/11/24). There remains uncertainty, but if as much rain falls as predicted, minor flooding could be possible. From 08:00 on 27/11/2024, minor flooding could affect a few gardens of properties in Langney Green. Fields and parkland including Shinewater Park might also be affected. Almost no rainfall is predicted on Wednesday afternoon, through to the weekend. The river through Langney should begin to fall by 23:00 on 27/11/2024, however river levels are likely to remain higher than normal until next week. River levels could end up similar to their height at the start of October 2024. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed at Langney Green, if you have them. We are operating our structures at Fence Bridge and Crumbles Gate to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 19:00 on 27/11/2024

items.description: River Adur West Branch
items.message: Between 15-30mm of rain is forecast through the early hours of Wednesday 27/11/24. There remains uncertainty, but if as much rain falls as predicted, flooding could be possible. From 09:00 on 27/11/2024 flooding could affect property at Slaughter Bridge on the Coolham road, as well as isolated farm buildings, fields and rural roads between Coolham and Henfield. It is possible water may approach gardens of Church Close, Shipley. Almost no rainfall is predicted Wednesday afternoon, through to the weekend. The river should begin to fall by 19:00 on 27/11/2024, and should return to normal from 06:00 on 28/11/2024. It is thought river levels could end up a little higher than following Storm Bert. Some roads, including the Coolham road at Slaughter Bridge, may be affected by flooding. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 15:00 on 27/11/2024

items.description: Plenty, Swalecliffe and West Brooks

items.message:

Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads along Swalecliffe Brook in Swalecliffe and around Herne Bay. River levels are currently expected to peak later on Wednesday morning.

Monitor local water levels and weather conditions and be prepared for further warnings. This message will be updated by 2pm on Wednesday 27 November, or as the situation changes.

items.message: Property flooding is expected. River levels are increasing quickly on the River Thame following heavy rainfall earlier in the week from Storm Bert. Therefore, flooding of properties, low lying land, and roads is likely early tomorrow morning, 27/11/2024. Areas most at risk are properties closest to the river where it passes through Dorchester.
